key_points: A suicide bombing at a Shiite mosque in Kandahar, Afghanistan killed at least 50 people and wounded at least 100.
This is the second major bombing in Afghanistan within a week, raising concerns about the rise of militant groups post-Taliban takeover.
No group has claimed responsibility for the Kandahar attack, though a similar attack in Kunduz was claimed by the Islamic State.
The attack highlights fears that the Taliban is unable to control other militant groups, including Al-Qaeda and the Islamic State.
The Islamic State considers Shiite Muslims heretics and often targets their places of worship.
A Taliban police chief was killed by the Islamic State in Konar province a day before the Kandahar mosque attack.
The Taliban, now controlling the entire country, faces pressure to maintain security nationwide.
Eyewitness reports describe multiple explosions and gunfire at the scene of the attack.
The United Nations Assistance Mission in Afghanistan condemned the attack, reporting a death toll of 30.
The Taliban ordered its fighters to arrest those behind the attack, condemning it as "a big crime".
spokespersons: Hafiz Abdul Hai Abbas (Health director for the province)
